Dos and don’ts: A brief guide guide
Do
Considerations for the dos
Do not
Considerations for the do nots
Introduce yourself, your role, and scope of practice within the setting, and the type/purpose of the evaluation
This is an opportunity for the individual to ask follow-up questions, especially regarding the limits of confidentiality, privacy, and mandated reporter status
Don’t deliver information or diagnostic feedback outside of your scope and competency
Abide by ethical guidelines and codes of conduct both within psychological practice and those within the health care setting, i. e., delivery of CPR is expected of psychologists in hospital settings
Utilize a comprehensive interview as an opportunity for assessment and intervention
This may be an individual’s first and only encounter with a mental health professional and may serve a way to facilitate their willingness to engage in the future
Don’t underestimate the value of the initial interview as a useful intervention
This allows the individual to experience validation and an opportunity to express and verbalize concerns that they may not have already shared
Use standardized screeners/diagnostic tools and be mindful of the individual’s engagement level
Awareness of the individual’s fatigue and sensory limitations, i. e., hearing aids, glasses, lighting, privacy screens, large-print materials
Don’t make a diagnosis based on limited or incomplete information
There may be a feeling of urgency in healthcare settings; however, it is crucial that all data and information be gathered to form an accurate diagnosis and treatment plan
Evaluate and rule out other potential diagnoses and comorbidities
Many individuals have more than one mental health disorder and medical condition, and each needs to be addressed
Don’t neglect the possibility that medical conditions could be contributing to psychiatric symptoms
Obstructive sleep apnea, thyroid conditions, and diabetes have similar and overlapping symptomologies with mental health diagnoses
Involve other disciplines and team members
Seek input from colleagues, other disciplines, and/or second opinions
Don’t isolate yourself in the diagnostic process
Utilize a chart review and consultation
Consider cultural, social, and individual factors
Ethically, this is considered evidence-based practice
Don’t allow personal biases and stereotypes to muddy your assessment
If there are any personal challenges that may interfere and can potentially cause harm, know when and how to refer out. Give yourself time to further reflect and engage with the challenge
Incorporate the individual’s strengths to promote resilience and autonomy
Strengths can underscore an individual’s ability to overcome challenges in the past and/or be utilized during treatment
Don’t dismiss the individual’s own description of their symptoms and experiences
Allowing the individual to describe symptoms in their own terms and past experiences with treatments can aid in tailoring the treatment plan and diagnostic clarification
Be aware of the individual’s modesty concerns by taking into consideration their state of dress/undress
If you notice the individual is wearing a hospital gown, or may be in an awkward position, seek out the help of available staff to accommodate their need
Don’t assume what does/does not make the individual comfortable or uncomfortable
Asking demonstrates conscientiousness and can build rapport
Provide feedback to the referral source and individual/healthcare agent in a timely manner
It can be valuable to thank your referral source, too!
Don’t neglect a follow-up
Failing to review important points or concerns can lead to missed information and unresolved issues
Provide additional referrals or specialty consults to refine diagnostic impressions
For example, in the case of poor sleep, rule out sleep apnea
Don’t place or request referrals without reviewing the chart to see what has been done already
This helps streamline the care the individual can get and provides a moment to remind them or explore why past referrals were not responded to
